Award.AwardTitle: COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH: Testing a new hypothesis for global patterns in leaf form using Viburnum (Adoxaceae)
Award.AbstractNarration: Scientists have long recognized a global pattern in leaf shape between tropical and temperate climates: tropical leaves have smooth margins while plants living in cold regions have leaves with teeth or lobes, like a birch or a maple. The relationship is so strong that paleobotanists use leaf shapes in fossil floras as a proxy for temperature, allowing for estimates of climate change through time. But there is still no mechanistic understanding of why this relationship exists. The PIs hypothesize that the evolution of complex leaf margins in temperate plants results in part from the way that young, immature leaves are packed into overwintering buds. This is inspired by recent mathematical models of efficient leaf folding within buds, and by observations of within-plant differences in leaf form. Viburnum is a lineage of ~170 species of woody shrubs and trees that have shifted between tropical and temperate forests many times throughout the past 50 million years, and exhibit the expected changes in leaf shape. The PIs will document timing of growth, leaf lifespan, and patterns of leaf-packing within buds, and gather additional data on a suite of relevant morphological and physiological traits on a set of Viburnum species spanning the tropical-temperate gradient. They will also continue long-term phenological monitoring of ~30 Viburnum species in a common garden. This is a highly collaborative and interdisciplinary project, involving biologists from four other nations as well as an applied mathematician. The PIs will also develop educational modules designed for elementary school children aimed to bridge the gap between math and biology, using origami and basic geometric principles to understand common leaf shapes.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Scientists have long recognized a global pattern in leaf shape between tropical and temperate climates: tropical leaves have smooth margins while plants living in cold regions have leaves with teeth or lobes, like a birch or a maple. The relationship is so strong that researchers use leaf shapes in fossil floras as a proxy for temperature, allowing for estimates of climate change through time. But there is still no mechanistic understanding of why this relationship exists. The PIs hypothesized that the evolution of complex leaf margins in temperate plants is correlated with their deciduous leaf habit, and this connection results in part from the way that young, immature leaves are packed into overwintering buds. This project explored these questions using the model lineage Viburnum, a group of ~170 species of  woody shrubs and trees that have shifted between tropical and temperate forests many times throughout the past 50 million years, and exhibit the expected changes in leaf shape. The PIs established a phenology monitoring transect spanning Borneo, Taiwan, and Japan, and discovered that the deciduous leafing habit is perfectly correlated with exposure to freezing temperatures; furthermore, leaf shape is perfectly correlated with being deciduous. The team also investigated the structure of vegetative buds in tropical and temperate species using microCT scanning imaging, and discovered that complex leaf shapes occur in species with large, efficiently packed overwintering buds. The team also studied within-species variation in these same traits in several wide-ranging North American species of Viburnumand found that within-species variation mirrored across-species variation, providing a rare link between population-level processes and broader macroevolutionary patterns. Taken together, the data collected during this award has led to the development of new models about the link between leaf form and climate, and more generally, about the past assembly of our modern day biomes. This award also supported the participation of graduate students in science outreach programs to elementary school students, the establishment of productive international collaborations between U.S. institutions and those in Taiwan and Japan, and the training of multiple postdoctoral associates, graduate students, and undergraduates. At this time, the award has produced 10 peer-reviewed publications, with 2 others in press, 1 under revision, and 4 additional papers still in preparation.
